of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Viet Nam has requested technical assistance (TA) from the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  strengthen  the  institutions  that  manage  the  country’s  water 
resources. The TA is included in the country operations business plan, 2009–2011 for Viet Nam 
and is consistent with Viet Nam’s country strategy and program, 2007–2010. The midterm 
review  of  the  country  strategy  and  program  called  for  an  integrated  water  resources 
management (IWRM) approach to planning strategies and work practices with a strong focus on 
institutional development in conjunction with water resources infrastructure development.1 This 
follows from the support provided under two earlier TA projects: (i) the Viet Nam Water Sector 
Review,  which  identified  key  water  management  issues  and  led  to  the  formulation  of  the 
government’s National Target Program (NTP) to improve the effectiveness of integrated use, 
management, and protection of water resources;2 and (ii) the Second Red River Basin Sector 
Project,  which  assisted  the  government  with  a  review  and  revision  of  the  Law  on  Water 
Resources (LWR).3  
 
2.  An ADB project review mission for the Second Red River Basin Project, conducted 2–20 
August 2010, identified the need for additional TA.4 This report is based on the understanding 
reached  with  the  government  regarding  the  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation 
arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and outline terms of reference for the TA.5 The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Viet Nam, a country not rich in water resources, will face numerous challenges in the 
future. Viet Nam has long dry seasons, and more than 60% of its water comes from other 
countries. Some major rivers, including the Red–Thai Binh river basin in northern Viet Nam, are 
stressed with inadequate flows of clean fresh water. Groundwater is contaminated by industrial 
waste, pesticides and fertilizer used in agriculture, and aquaculture. However, Viet Nam has 
struggled to implement sustainable resource management approaches, and the government 
has failed to enforce the regulatory frameworks it has adopted.  
 
4.  Legal and institutional arrangements are not clear and water rights are not defined, 
leading to conflict, inefficient and unsustainable investments, and stress on water resources. 
The country has struggled to maintain or replace old and dilapidated infrastructure. Climate 
change and the prospect of rising sea levels are complicating these serious challenges. The 
1998 LWR urgently needs updating to address the legal and institutional arrangements that are 
required.

2   
5.  IWRM includes the following features: (i) effective management and conservation of 
water focused on efficient water use in all sectors to ensure a sufficient supply, (ii) a water rights 
framework,  and  (iii)  river  basin  plans  with  water  allocation  rules.  Improving  the  social 
environment and living conditions of people requires more and larger investments in water-
related projects for pro-poor rural development, irrigation diversification, and stronger rural water 
supply and sanitation.  
 
6.  The government’s approval and implementation of the NTP will be essential for the 
adoption of IWRM principles. The NTP covers the 13 main river basins in Viet Nam, but 
prioritizes three of them: (i) the Red–Thai Binh river basin in the north, including the capital 
Hanoi; (ii) the Dong Nai river basin in the south, including Ho Chi Minh City, the largest city and 
commercial  center;  and  (iii)  the  Cuu  Long  (Mekong)  river  basin  in  the  far  south,  which 
encompasses the Mekong Delta. Together these three river basins account for 48% of the 
country's physical area and almost 70% of its population. They also produce about 70% of the 
gross domestic product and have more than 80% of the country’s water resources.  
 
7.  ADB has made considerable investments in water resources development in the Red–
Thai Binh River Basin, including four loans with major irrigation and drainage components along 
with institutional development initiatives.6 These initiatives have demonstrated the need to (i) 
strengthen the capacity to develop the water resources sector further and ensure the success of 
future investments, and (ii) base project planning on a river basin development approach that 
addresses key constraints in an integrated manner. Successful capacity development projects 
feature  thorough  project  preparation,  close  coordination  among  funding  agencies,  and 
administration by the resident mission. 
 
8.  The TA is consistent with the draft assessment strategy and road map for the agriculture, 
natural  resources,  and  environment  sector, 7  which  includes  natural  resources  and  the 
environment as one of its three major support areas. The TA will also add value to ADB's 
program  for  Viet  Nam  and  has  the  potential  to  strengthen  cooperation  with  international 
development  partners  supporting  the  development  of  the  country's  water  resources  sector 
through institutional and operational capacity development.8 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact will be better management and development of the water resources sector, 
including the adoption of an effective water resources development strategy and investment

program for the Red–Thai Binh river basin by 2015. The outcome will be greater capacity of the 
Ministry  of  Natural  Resources  and  Environment  (MONRE)  to  support  policy  initiatives  and 
implement investment projects, including the government’s endorsement and acceptance of a 
new legal framework for water resources management by November 2011. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will support MONRE’s adoption of IWRM principles through (i) continued support 
for the revision of the LWR, and (ii) the establishment of planning tasks leading to a sector 
strategy and investment program for the development of the Red–Thai Binh river basin water 
resources.9 The main outputs will be the documents needed for the submission of the amended 
LWR by March 2011,10 and the planning tasks by June 2012. 
 
1.  Support for Preparation of Amended Law on Water Resources 
11.  Since February 2009, ADB has provided TA to support the review of the LWR (footnote 
3). The Government of the Netherlands also provided funding on a grant basis. That support will 
end at the end of October 2010. 
 
12.  MONRE must submit the amended LWR and all supporting documents to the National 
Assembly  by  March  2011.  This  TA  will  support  MONRE  over  the  5  months  between  the 
conclusion of the TA project that initiated the LWR review (footnote 3) and the submission of the 
amended LWR at the end of March 2011. During that period, MONRE will (i) revise the draft 
LWR  to  address  stakeholder  comments  and  finalize  the  LWR,  (ii)  finalize  the  impact 
assessment report, (iii) complete the draft implementation decree, (iv) consult with stakeholders 
on the draft LWR before finalization, and (v) complete the submission of all documents.  
 
13.  A revised draft LWR has been prepared, which includes the following key features: (i) 
better planning to provide the foundation for good management and protection of the country’s 
water resources; (ii) water source protection and control over activities that degrade water 
resources;  (iii)  clearer  water  use  rights  and  more  efficient  management  of  water  use;  (iv) 
responses to natural resource threats and damage caused by water; (v) information gathering 
and sharing; (vi) a wider range of economic instruments, including fees for the efficient delivery 
of  water  services,  charges  for  water  use  and  wastewater  discharge,  and  private  sector 
contributions  to  infrastructure  projects;  and  (vii)  clearer  organizational  and  administrative 
arrangements.  Without  continued  support  for  the  LWR  revisions,  ADB  and  MONRE  are 
concerned that many of the innovations and key features proposed in the draft LWR may be lost 
or watered down as they are exposed to a broader range of stakeholders. 
 
2.  Planning Tasks for the Red–Thai Binh River Basin 
14.  The government's NTP, which is in final stages of formulation and approval, will provide 
the basis for international development partners working in water sector development, including 
ADB, to prepare strategies and road maps for investment. The NTP presents the government’s 
broad strategy and a proposed program of investments for water resources development with

river basin management. They are also proposed in the draft amended LWR.  
10 Including the final draft amended LWR, the final impact assessment report, and the final draft of the government

4   
one of its highest priorities for the Red–Thai Binh river basin.11 The government strategy and 
program of investments will need to be refined further before they are included in ADB’s lending 
and nonlending program.  
 
15.  The TA will support MONRE in addressing the planning tasks for the development of the 
water resources of the Red–Thai Binh river basin. The planning tasks will be undertaken before 
the formulation of a detailed river basin plan as a rapid assessment to identify objectives, 
priorities, and general solutions for the basin; and to provide a framework and plan of activities 
for managing water resources. In the Red–Thai Binh river basin, this will involve a sector 
strategy and investment program for the development of its water resources.  
 
16.  The outcomes and targets for the river basin will not be exhaustive. Instead they will 
focus on the outcomes that reflect the highest priorities and are good indicators of overall 
improvement. Similarly,  targets  selected  will  be  those  that  are  most  likely  to  produce  the 
greatest gains towards the outcomes in the short term. Achievement of the targets will allow 
MONRE to take a significant step in the process of continuous improvement. This will involve 
consultation  with  the  community  concerned  and  an  assessment  of  social,  economic,  and 
environmental impacts over time. 
 
17.  The planning tasks for the development of the Red–Thai Binh river basin will provide a 
framework plan of action and investment for managing water-dependent and water-impacting 
activities in the river basin. They will be implemented by the provinces, ministries, and state 
management agencies with interests in this river basin. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF-IV). The TA is estimated to cost $650,000 equivalent with ADB contributing $580,000 
and the government providing $70,000 equivalent. The cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The  executing  agency  will  be  MONRE,  which  will  implement  the  TA  through  its 
Department of Water Resources Management and provide office accommodation, counterpart 
staff, and logistical support. 
 
20.  The TA will require about 54 person-months of consulting services, consisting of 14 
person-months international inputs and 40 person-months national inputs. It will be implemented 
over 20 months with an additional 3 months for TA closing. The consultants currently supporting 
the LWR revision will be extended through the firm contracted for this purpose by single-source 
selection as the tasks involved are a natural continuation of their previous work.12 The firm’s 
main  role  under  the  TA  is  to  provide  the  same  six  consultants  (five  nationals  and  one 
international) to continue work on the revision of the LWR, which started in early 2009 and has

proceeded effectively with their support.13 The outline terms of reference for consultants is in 
Appendix 3. 
 
21.  The consultants to be employed on the planning tasks will be recruited by individual 
consultant selection. They will work closely with the Viet Nam Resident Mission’s water team14 
and will be able to draw on the expertise and in-house resources already available. 
 
22.  ADB  will  engage  the  consultants  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  Procurement  under  the  TA  will  be  in 
accordance  with  ADB's  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time). 
Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  in  accordance  with  the  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
23.  ADB will manage the TA through its staff posted in the resident mission, which will allow 
continual communication and on-site monitoring of the TA project and the consultants’ progress 
in carrying out their work. The project officer will meet frequently with MONRE to discuss 
progress  and  attempt  to  ensure  effective  application  of  the  TA.  The  government  drafting 
committee will scrutinize the LWR outputs. The outputs related to the planning tasks for the 
development  of  the  Red–Thai  Binh  river  basin  will  be  widely  circulated  for  comments  to 
government agencies, international development partners, and ADB. 
 
24.  TA outputs, policy recommendations, and lessons learned will be disseminated through 
(i) seminars, workshops, focus groups, and conferences; (ii) consultations with international 
development  partners  and  civil  society;  (iii)  ADB's  water  community  of  practice;  and  (iv) 
publication of at least one knowledge product. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $580,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Viet Nam for Capacity Building for River Basin Water Resources Planning, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
13 The vice minister of MONRE has requested that the same consultants be extended for this work as a change in 
personnel would be disruptive at this late stage in the process. Furthermore, MONRE and ADB have assessed the 
performance of the firm and its consultants as highly satisfactory. 
14 The Viet Nam Resident Mission established its water team in October 2009 to provide a stronger policy-based 
approach to the formulation of ADB’s program for the sector. The team has two international consultants (one 
urban water supply and sanitation specialist and one rural water supply and sanitation specialist), one national 
consultant (regulatory framework specialist), and one national research assistant.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  These terms of reference are for the two main outputs to be addressed under the 
technical assistance (TA) for Capacity Building for River Basin Water Resources Planning: (i) 
preparation of documents for the submission of the Law on Water Resources (LWR) to the 
National Assembly, and (ii) formulation of planning tasks leading to a sector strategy and 
investment program for the development of the water resources of the Red–Thai Binh river 
basin.  
 
A.  Support for Preparation of Amended Law on Water Resources 
1.  Background 
2.  The implementation of this TA output will require the services of one international and 
five  national  consultants.  The  consultants  currently  supporting  the  LWR  revisions  will  be 
extended through the firm contracted for this purpose by single-source selection as the tasks 
involved are a natural continuation of their previous work. The consultants will work closely with 
their counterpart staff in the Department of Water Resources Management (DWRM), and with 
the LWR editing team and steering committee set up by the Ministry of Natural Resources and 
Environment (MONRE). This output will require 1.8 person-months of international consultant 
inputs and 25 person-months national consultant inputs.  
 
3.  The international consultant has expertise in water (surface and groundwater) policy and 
institutions,  understands  the  international  principles  and  approaches  to  integrated  water 
resources management (IWRM) and their application, and understands the legal frameworks for 
water management. The consultant will work mainly from his international home base to ensure 
quality control of the final outputs produced for the LWR. The national consultants, who will work 
out  of  an  office  established  at  DWRM,  will  include  a  national  team  leader  with  extensive 
expertise in water resources management and an understanding of IWRM and legal frameworks. 
National expertise in water policy and institutions, existing water management situation and 
status (surface and groundwater), and water source protection is currently being applied to the 
review and revision of the LWR. The work is expected to begin from the closing date of the 
previous TA1 and continue over 5 months from 1 November 2010 to 31 March 2011. 
 
2.  Consultant Activities and Outputs 
4.  The consultants will support MONRE as it (i) amends the draft LWR in response to 
comments,  and  finalizes  the  LWR;  (ii)  finalizes  the  impact  assessment  report  (IAR);  (iii) 
completes the draft implementation decree; (iv) consults widely on the LWR; and (v) completes 
all submission documents. The consultants will support MONRE in the following areas: 
 
(i)  Finalizing the LWR

draft. 
(b)   Meetings of the steering committee and editing team to consider the draft 
LWR. 
(c)   Public exhibition of the draft LWR. 
(d)   Formal referral of the draft LWR to ministries for official comment.

B.  Planning Tasks for the Red–Thai Binh River Basin  
1.  Background 
5.  The output will be the production of planning tasks for the Red–Thai Binh river basin, 
setting out a strategy and investment plan for the basin. Planning tasks are based on existing 
knowledge  and  understanding  (no  additional  research  or  major  data  collection  will  be 
undertaken). They will concentrate on high-level issues, outcomes, and solutions. The planning 
tasks will: 
(i)  Identify  agreed  objectives—what  are  the  broad  outcomes  that  river  basin 
planning should achieve? 
(ii)  Identify priorities for activities—what are the key areas in which management 
activities are required? This may be in water allocation, pollution treatment, flood 
mitigation, protection of the stability of the river channel structure, or groundwater 
management for a specified area. 
(iii)  Propose general solutions—what needs to be done to achieve the objectives? In 
some cases, these may require the development of a component plan for a river 
or a groundwater area. In others, the solutions may be more general, such as the 
need for a community awareness campaign or for capacity building. 
 
6.  The planning tasks will provide clear directions for all water management in the river 
basin, including the need to create component plans addressing 
(i)  water allocation, 
(ii)  water source protection, and 
(iii)  management of natural hazards (including flooding). 
                                                 
2  A draft of the implementation decree must be submitted to the National Assembly at the same time as the LWR. 
This will detail how the provisions of the LWR will be implemented. As such, it is an important document that will 
help the National Assembly understand the provisions.

12  Appendix 3 
 
7.  The  implementation  of  this  TA  output  will  require  the  services  of  one  international 
consultant and one national consultant. Individual consultants will be engaged through ADB’s 
individual consultant selection to provide these services and work closely with counterpart staff 
of DWRM and MONRE. This output will require 12.2 person-months of services of international 
consultant inputs and 15 person-months national consultant inputs. The international consultant 
will be the team leader. The consultant will have expertise in surface water and groundwater 
policy and institutions, and will understand international principles and approaches to IWRM and 
their application. The national consultant will have expertise in water resources management 
and will understand IWRM, water policy and institutions, and water source protection. The work 
is expected to take place intermittently over 18 months between 1 January 2011 and 30 June 
2012. 
 
2.  Consultant Activities and Outputs 
8.  The consultants will support MONRE as it (i) prepares status report, including a review 
of existing policies and data collection, for the Red–Thai Binh river basin; (ii) conduct meetings 
with sector stakeholders of Red–Thai Binh river basin to identify issues, threats, and objectives; 
(iii) formulate recommendations for basin planning activities and appropriate role sharing and 
responsibilities of central, provincial, and district water agencies and other stakeholders; (iv) 
develop planning tasks—strategies and methodologies, road map, and investment program—for 
the development of the river basin; and (v) finalize the sector strategy and investment program 
for development of the river basin. The details of the consultants’ activities are as follows: 
 
(i)  Prepare status report for the Red–Thai Binh river basin 
(a)   Prepare a stakeholder participation plan. 
(b)   Identify  the  status  and  trends  of  the  water  sources  of  the  basin 
(hydromorphology,  water  quality  and  environmental  health,  water 
extraction and use, damage caused by the harmful effects of the water, 
economic profile, social profile, and community values). 
(c)   Identify  management  arrangements,  including  legal  and  institutional 
aspects, international agreements, current monitoring programs, licensing 
status, capacity to manage inspection and compliance, and community 
participation mechanisms. 
(d)   Review and update terms of reference and TA scope. 
 
(ii)  Establish river basin issues, threats, and objectives 
(a)   Establish a water vision for the basin and water management principles. 
(b)   Identify the processes and activities that present the greatest risk to the 
community values and assets of the basin. 
(c)   Establish  resource  objectives,  social  and  economic  objectives,  and 
management objectives. 
 
(iii)  Formulate recommendations for basin planning activities and appropriate 
roles of stakeholders 
(a)   Establish  which  of  the  component  planning  activities  are  to  be 
developed—water source protection, allocation, and/or natural hazards—
to achieve the objectives and resolve the issues identified. 
(b)   Recommend  appropriate  role  sharing  and  responsibilities  of  central, 
provincial, and district water agencies. 
(c)  Promote the participation of government officials in relevant conferences 
and training.

Appendix 3  13 
(iv)  Develop actions, strategies, and road map for the river basin  
(a)   Develop and appraise a range of management options for water sources 
considered at risk, and make decision about the measures and specific 
provisions that will be included in the planning tasks and road map. 
(b)  Draft a final document of planning tasks (strategies and methodologies) 
for river basin management and development. 
(c)   Prepare  workshops  to  vet  and  review  the  Red–Thai  Binh  river  basin 
development plan. 
(d)  Define and draft knowledge products. 
(e)  Develop an action plan for the adoption of policy recommendations. 
(f)  Prepare draft final report and recommendations. 
 
(v)  Finalize river basin sector strategy and investment program 
(a)   Solicit comments on the final draft strategy and road map for the river 
basin, and finalize reports and strategies. 
(b)  Define next steps and follow-up actions. 
(c)  Finalize  at  least  one  knowledge  product  and  identify  appropriate 
dissemination channel. 
(d)  Make a presentation to ADB’s water community of practice on the Red–
Thai Binh river basin sector strategy and investment program.
